context.text: How does it affect his manners? [Illustration: _Bones of the human body._] CHAPTER IV. WHAT IS ALCOHOL? [Illustration: R]IPE grapes are full of juice. This juice is mostly water, sweetened with a sugar of its own. It is flavored with something which makes us know, the moment we taste it, that it is grape-juice, and not cherry-juice or plum-juice. Apples also contain water, sugar, and apple flavor; and cherries contain water, sugar, and cherry flavor. The same is true of other fruits. They all, when ripe, have the water and the sugar; and each has a flavor of its own. Ripe grapes are sometimes gathered and put into great tubs called vats. In these the juice is squeezed out. In some countries, this squeezing is done by bare-footed men who jump into the vats and press the grapes with their feet. The grape-juice is then drawn off from the skins and seeds and left standing in a warm place. Bubbles soon begin to rise and cover the top of it with froth. The juice is all in motion. [Illustration: _Picking grapes and making wine._] If the cook had wished to use this grape-juice to make jelly, she would say: "Now, I can not make my grape-jelly, for the grape-juice is spoiled." the body which need it, comes from fat-making foods. In cold weather, we need more fatty food than we do in summer, just as in cold countries people need such food all the time. The Esquimaux, who live in the lands of snow and ice, catch a great many walrus and seal, and eat a great deal of fat meat. You would not be well unless you ate some fat or butter or oil. WHAT WILL MAKE FAT? Sugar will make fat, and so will starch, cream, rice, butter, and fat meat. As milk will make muscle and fat and bones, it is the best kind of food. Here, again, it is the earth that sends us our food. Fat meat comes from animals well fed on grain and grass; sugar, from sugar-cane, maple-trees, or beets; oil, from olive-trees; butter, from cream; and starch, from potatoes, and from corn, rice, and other grains. Green apples and other unripe fruits are not yet ready to be eaten. The starch which we take for food has to be changed into sugar, before it can mix with the blood and help feed the body. As the sun ripens fruit, it changes its starch to sugar. You can tell this by the difference in the taste of ripe and unripe apples. CANDY. Most children like candy so well, that they are in danger of eating more sugar than is good for them.

When you next try to pick a "drum-stick," remember that you are eating the strong muscles by which the chicken or turkey moved his legs as he walked about the yard. The parts that have the most work to do, need the strongest muscles. Did you ever see the swallows flying about the eaves of a barn? Do they have very stout legs? No! They have very small legs and feet, because they do not need to walk. They need to fly. The muscles that move the wings are fastened to the breast. These breast muscles of the swallow must be large and strong. EXERCISE OF THE MUSCLES. People who work hard with any part of the body make the muscles of that part very strong. The blacksmith has big, strong muscles in his arms because he uses them so much. You are using your muscles every day, and this helps them to grow. Once I saw a little girl who had been very sick. She had to lie in bed for many weeks. Before her sickness she had plenty of stout muscles in her arms and legs and was running about the house from morning till night, carrying her big doll in her arms. After her sickness, she could hardly walk ten steps, and would rather sit and look at her playthings than try to lift them. She had to make new muscles as fast as possible. Running, coasting, games of ball, and all brisk play and work, help to make strong muscles.

the joint. What you feel, is a muscle (m[)u]s'sl), and it works your joints very much as the rubber strap works the hinge of the door. One end of the muscle is fastened to the bone just below the elbow joint; and the other end, higher up above the joint. When it tightens, or contracts, as we say, it bends the joint. When the arm is straightened, the muscle returns to its first shape. There is another muscle on the outside of the arm which stretches when this one shortens, and so helps the working of the joint. Every joint has two or more muscles of its own to work it. Think how many there must be in our fingers! If we should undertake to count all the muscles that move our whole bodies, it would need more counting than some of you could do. TENDONS. You can see muscles on the dinner table; for they are only lean meat. [Illustration: _Tendons of the hand._] They are fastened to the bones by strong cords, called tendons (t[)e]n'd[)o]nz). These tendons can be seen in the leg of a chicken or turkey. They sometimes hold the meat so firmly that it is hard for you to get it off. When you next try to pick a "drum-stick," remember that you are eating the strong muscles by which the chicken or turkey moved his legs

MUSCLES. [Illustration: W]HAT makes the limbs move? You have to take hold of the door to move it back and forth; but you need not take hold of your arm to move that. What makes it move? Sometimes a door or gate is made to shut itself, if you leave it open. This can be done by means of a wide rubber strap, one end of which is fastened to the frame of the door near the hinge, and the other end to the door, out near its edge. When we push open the door, the rubber strap is stretched; but as soon as we have passed through, the strap tightens, draws the door back, and shuts it. If you stretch out your right arm, and clasp the upper part tightly with your left hand, then work the elbow joint strongly back and forth, you can feel something under your hand draw up, and then lengthen out again, each time you bend the joint. What you feel, is a muscle (m[)u]s'sl), and it works your joints very much as the rubber

to make jelly, she would say: "Now, I can not make my grape-jelly, for the grape-juice is spoiled." WHAT IS THIS CHANGE IN THE GRAPE-JUICE? The sugar in the grape-juice is changing into something else. It is turning into alcohol and a gas[A] that moves about in little bubbles in the liquid, and rising to the top, goes off into the air. The alcohol is a thin liquid which, mixed with the water, remains in the grape-juice. The sugar is gone; alcohol and the bubbles of gas are left in its place. This alcohol is a liquid poison. A little of it will harm any one who drinks it; much of it would kill the drinker. Ripe grapes are good food; but grape-juice, when its sugar has turned to alcohol, is not a safe drink for any one. It is poisoned by the alcohol. WINE. This changed grape-juice is called wine. It is partly water, partly alcohol, and it still has the grape flavor in it. Wine is also made from currants, elderberries, and other fruits, in very much the same way as from grapes. People sometimes make it at home from the fruits that grow in their own gardens, and think there is no alcohol in it, because they do not put any in. But you know that the alcohol is made in the fruit-juice itself by the change of the sugar

unripe apples. CANDY. Most children like candy so well, that they are in danger of eating more sugar than is good for them. You would starve if fed only on sugar. We would not need to be quite so much afraid of a little candy if it were not for the poison with which it is often . Even what is called pure, white candy is sometimes not really such. There is a simple way by which you can find this out for yourselves. If you put a spoonful of sugar into a tumbler of water, it will all dissolve and disappear. Put a piece of white candy into a tumbler of water; and, if it is made of pure sugar only, it will dissolve and disappear. If it is not, you will find at the bottom of the tumbler some white earth. This is not good food for anybody. Candy-makers often put it into candy in place of sugar, because it is cheaper than sugar. REVIEW QUESTIONS.           1. Why do we need food?           2. How do people get water to drink?           3. Why is it not safe to drink water that has been           standing in lead pipes?           4. Why is the water of a well

Dill and a number of assistants are engaged in preparing the specimens for exhibition. The logs as they reach the workroom are wrapped in bagging and inclosed in cases, this method being used so that the bark, with its growth of lichens and delicate exfoliations, shall not be injured while the logs are in process of transportation from various parts of the country to this city. The logs are each 6 feet in length, and each is the most perfect specimen of its class that could be found by the experts employed in making the collection. With the specimens of the trees come to the museum also specimens of the foliage and the fruits and flowers of the tree. These come from all parts of the Union--from Alaska on the north to Texas on the south, from Maine on the east to California on the west--and there is not a State or Territory in the Union which has not a representative in this collection of logs. On arrival here the logs are green, and the first thing in the way of treatment after their arrival is to season them, a work requiring great care to prevent them from "checking," as it is technically called, or "season cracking," as the unscientific term the splitting of the wood in radiating lines during the seasoning process. As is well known, the sap-wood of a tree seasons much more quickly than does the heart of the wood. The prevention of this splitting is very necessary in preparing these specimens for exhibition, for when once the wood

1. **Title**: Potash Soap Manufacturing
2. **Summary**: The topic revolves around the production and use of potash soap, highlighting its superiority over soda soap, especially in washing wool and woolen fabrics. The discussion includes the importance of using pure caustic potash, the process of making neutral potash soap, and its applications in household and laundry purposes. Additionally, the text touches on the use of cotton seed oil as a suitable alternative in soap making. The community also explores unrelated topics, such as surveying and astronomy, but the primary focus remains on potash soap and its manufacturing process.
3. **Keywords**: Potash Soap, Caustic Potash, Soap Manufacturing, Cotton Seed Oil, Laundry Purposes

1. **Title**: Life in 19th Century Rodman
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe life in 19th century Rodman, focusing on the experiences of Angeline Stickney and her family. The writings touch on various aspects, including the cruel practice of slavery, the usefulness of the Sugar Maple tree, and the daily life of Angeline, who faces hardships but remains determined and ambitious. The community is portrayed as traditional, with limited access to education and modern amenities. The writings also highlight the importance of family, self-reliance, and personal growth. Despite the challenges, Angeline finds joy in nature and pursues her interests in learning and music.
3. **Keywords**: Rodman, 19th Century, Angeline Stickney, Sugar Maple, Slavery

1. **Title**: The Nature of Bad Temper
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the complexities of a person's bad temper, specifically that of a character named Touchwood. His temper is described as pugnacious and contradicting, often leading to hurtful behavior towards others. Despite this, he is capable of sympathy and kindness, but his attempts at making amends often come across as insincere. The text also touches on the idea that individuals with uncertain tempers may believe it adds to their charm, but in reality, it can be repulsive and damaging to relationships. Furthermore, the discussion extends to the concept of how such temperaments can affect public figures and writers, leading to a lack of genuine impressions and a tendency to prioritize self-image over meaningful contributions.
3. **Keywords**: Bad Temper, Relationships, Insincerity, Public Figures, Self-Image

1. **Title**: Effects of Alcohol Consumption
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss the negative effects of alcohol consumption on the human body. Alcohol is formed through the fermentation of sugar in fruit juices, such as grape and apple, and can be found in drinks like wine and cider. Consuming alcohol can lead to addiction, harm the body and mind, and even cause death. The texts also touch on the importance of a healthy diet and the role of different food groups in maintaining a strong body. Additionally, the dangers of tobacco use and the importance of avoiding harmful substances are mentioned. Overall, the texts emphasize the need for responsible behavior and healthy habits to maintain overall well-being.
3. **Keywords**: Alcohol, Addiction, Health, Nutrition, Tobacco

1. **Title**: Botany and Tree Collections
2. **Summary**: The provided text chunks discuss various aspects of botany, including the characteristics of specific tree species, such as the Maidenhair tree and the Gingkgo. The collection of woods at the American Museum of Natural History is also described, featuring 394 logs representing different tree varieties. Additionally, the importance of nutrition, particularly the role of nitrogenous substances in the human body, is explored. The prevention of scurvy and the use of preserved foods are also mentioned. The text also touches on the preparation of tree specimens for exhibition and the challenges of preserving them.
3. **Keywords**: Botany, Tree Species, Nutrition, Scurvy, Wood Preservation

1. **Ancient Musical Instruments**
2. The ancient Egyptians and other civilizations had a wide range of musical instruments, including trumpets, drums, harps, flutes, and whistles. These instruments were often depicted in sculptures and paintings, providing valuable information about their construction and use. The Egyptians, in particular, had a sophisticated understanding of music and instrument-making, with evidence of various instruments dating back to around 1500 B.C. The discovery of ancient instruments, such as the reindeer-bone whistle and the stag's-horn pipe, has also shed light on the early history of music. The use of these instruments in ancient cultures, including Egypt and Asia, has been well-documented, with many examples found in museums and tombs.
3. **Keywords**: Ancient Instruments, Egyptian Music, Archaeology, Music History, Instrument-Making

1. **Historical Musical Instruments**
2. **Summary**: The text discusses various historical musical instruments, including the lute, tamboura, kanoon, carillon, and organ. The lute, in particular, is mentioned as being played in the Persian style, with a system of seventeen intervals in the compass of an octave. The carillon, a musical instrument composed of multiple bells, is also described, with its origins and evolution in European countries. The text highlights the unique characteristics of each instrument and their suitability for producing specific musical effects. The development of musical instruments has led to the creation of new musical compositions and expressions. The history of bell-ringing and peal-ringing in England is also explored, with descriptions of the techniques and instruments used.
3. **Keywords**: Historical instruments, Lute, Carillon, Organ, Musical evolution

1. **Human Anatomy Basics**
2. The provided text chunks discuss the fundamental components of the human body, including muscles, bones, and nerves. Muscles are described as lean meat that works joints, similar to a rubber strap working a door hinge. The importance of exercise in strengthening muscles is emphasized, and the negative effects of alcohol and idleness on muscle health are noted. The text also touches on the structure and function of bones, including the spine and joints, and the role of nerves in sending messages throughout the body.
3. **Keywords**: Human Anatomy, Muscles, Bones, Nerves

1. **Title**: Moroccan Trade and Geography
2. **Summary**: The text chunks discuss various aspects of Morocco, including its trade, geography, and culture. The country's ports, such as Mogador, Tangier, and Rabat, are major hubs for the export of goods like almonds, wool, and olive oil, and the import of goods like cotton, sugar, and tea. The chunks also describe the country's cities, like Fez, Taza, and Zawiat-Muley-Driss, and their historical and cultural significance. Additionally, the text mentions the influence of Grand Marabouts, or religious leaders, in the country's governance and the role of the Shereefs, or descendants of the Prophet Muhammad, in Moroccan society.
3. **Keywords**: Morocco, Trade, Geography, Marabouts, Shereefs

1. **Title**: Life in 19th Century Kentucky
2. **Summary**: The text chunks describe life in 19th century Kentucky, focusing on the experiences of characters such as Tom Fairfield, Don Carlo, and Aunt Katy. The stories touch on themes of family, religion, and social class, providing a glimpse into the daily lives and struggles of people living in Kentucky during this time period. The characters face various challenges, including poverty, illness, and personal struggles, but also find joy and community in their relationships and faith. The text also mentions historical events and cultural practices, such as the "jerks" phenomenon in church services and the importance of navigation on the Ohio river.
3. **Keywords**: Kentucky, 19th century, family, religion, social class

1. **Title**: Historical American Frontier
2. **Summary**: The given text chunks appear to be excerpts from a historical novel or narrative about the American frontier, specifically focusing on the regions of Kentucky, Arkansas, and the Mississippi River. The stories touch on themes of conflict, settlement, and daily life in the early days of American history, including interactions with Native American tribes, steam navigation, and the establishment of wood yards. The narrative also explores the characters and experiences of individuals living in these areas, such as Tom Fairfield, Don and Dan Carlo, and others. The text weaves together elements of history, adventure, and social commentary, providing a glimpse into the lives of people in the American frontier during the 18th and 19th centuries.
3. **Keywords**: American Frontier, Kentucky, Mississippi River, Steam Navigation, Settlement

1. **Title**: Life in Canada City

The community is portrayed as vibrant, with social interactions and relationships between characters like Cissy, her friend Piney, and various men, including the Reverend Mr. Windibrook and a young engineer. The narrative touches on themes of beauty, social status, and the complexities of human connections in a small, close-knit community. The stories also mention the town's layout, its church, and the contrast between the natural beauty of the surrounding landscape and the harsh realities of mining life.
3. **Keywords**: Canada City, Mining Town, Social Interactions, Cissy Trixit, Community Life
